questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of chest pain and rapid heart beating over the past two months. During this period, he has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss, malaise, pain in both knees, and diffuse muscle pain. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection and was started on tenofovir. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities except for tachycardia. There are several ulcerations around the ankle and calves bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11 g/dL


Leukocyte count
14,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
80 mm/h


Serum



 Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

negative


 Hepatitis B surface antigen
positive


Urine



 Protein

+2


 RBC

6-7/hpf


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis often manifests with fever, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia, muscular pain, cardiac symptoms (angina pectoris), and elevated ESR. It is also associated with chronic hepatitis B. However, Takayasu arteritis would typically manifest with decreased bilateral brachial and radial pulses (“pulseless disease”). Moreover, it typically occurs in Asian females under the age of 40 years.

B) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) typically manifests with elevated ESR and constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss). However, this patient lacks important findings of GCA (e.g., pulse-synchronous throbbing, dull headache, temporal tenderness, and jaw claudication). Although GCA is also often associated with polymyalgia rheumatica that typically manifests with proximal muscle pain (shoulder, pelvic girdle) and stiffness, this patient has diffuse muscle and knee pain. Lastly, GCA is most common in women over the age of 50 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Churg-Strauss syndrome is a type of small vessel vasculitis that may present with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms. However, patients with Churg-Strauss syndrome often have a history of recurrent asthma attacks and positive testing for pANCA.

D) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), like most vasculitides, usually involves multiple organ systems, as seen in this patient (skin, kidneys, heart). The absence of pANCA and pulmonary symptoms, as well as the association with hepatitis B (and hepatitis C), helps to differentiate PAN from other forms of vasculitis. Muscle biopsy of this patient would most likely show transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

PAN should be always considered in young adults presenting with stroke or myocardial infarction.

E) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by progressive inflammation and thrombosis that results in claudication with absent peripheral pulses and cold extremities. It may cause ulcerations of the distal extremities and muscle pain. However, findings would usually include migratory thrombophlebitis and Raynaud's phenomenon, as well as normal ESR levels. Thromboangiitis obliterans would also not explain the involvement of multiple organ systems.

F) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener's granulomatosis) can manifest with malaise, arthralgias, skin lesions, as well as renal and cardiac symptoms and increased ESR. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia) suggests a different diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that often manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms. However, patients with microscopic polyangiitis commonly have pulmonary symptoms, (e.g., hemoptysis). Furthermore, individuals with microscopic polyangiitis are pANCA positive in ∼ 70% of cases.
questions.hint: This patient presents with nonspecific symptoms (fever, arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain, palpitations), and renal manifestations (proteinuria, hematuria), as well as elevated ESR and leukocytosis, all of which are findings consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. A negative pANCA and a history of a hepatitis B infection indicate a certain subtype of vasculitis that usually spares the lungs.

questions.text: A previously healthy 48-year-old man comes to the physician for a 3-month history of myalgias and recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain and dizziness. He has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during this period. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 160/102 mm Hg. Physical examination shows lacy, purplish discoloration of the skin with multiple erythematous, tender subcutaneous nodules on the lower legs. Some of the nodules have central ulcerations. Serum studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 76 mm/h and creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. Renal MR angiography shows irregular areas of dilation and constriction in the renal arteries bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Multinuclear giant cells with elastic membrane fragmentation on arterial biopsy
Transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis on arterial biopsy
Pulmonary artery microaneurysms on pulmonary angiography
Presence of anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies in the serum
Presence of anti-proteinase 3 antibodies in the serum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multinuclear giant cells with elastic membrane fragmentation on arterial biopsy are seen in giant cell arteritis, which can cause myalgia (polymyalgia rheumatica) and systemic symptoms such as fever and weight loss. Chest pain, livedo reticularis, and ulcerating, tender subcutaneous nodules have also been reported in some patients with GCA. However, these nodules are found on the scalp and neck rather than the lower limbs and would be accompanied by headache, jaw claudication, and/or visual impairment, which are not reported here. Also, renal aneurysms would not be expected in GCA. PAN, in turn, is not associated with the formation of multinuclear giant cells.

B) CORRECT:

Transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis on arterial biopsy is characteristic of PAN, which is a necrotizing vasculitis of medium-sized arteries. Renal artery involvement, which occurs in about 60% of cases of PAN, can result in prerenal azotemia and hypertension. Involvement of the coronary arteries can cause angina, as seen here, and involvement of the mesenteric vessels can lead to symptoms of mesenteric ischemia (e.g., abdominal pain, melena). Affected patients can develop numerous microaneurysms and spasms that are readily detected on an arteriogram. PAN is often associated with hepatitis B and hepatitis C infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary artery microaneurysms on pulmonary angiography may be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis, both of which can cause systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, myalgia), chest pain, livedo reticularis, tender cutaneous nodules, and hypertension with increased creatinine due to RPGN. However, renal aneurysms would not be expected in either of these conditions. For unknown reasons, the pulmonary arteries are characteristically spared in PAN.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies (MPO-ANCA or p-ANCA) in the serum suggests microscopic polyangiitis, which can cause systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, myalgia), chest pain, livedo reticularis, tender cutaneous nodules, and hypertension with increased creatinine due to RPGN. However, renal aneurysms would not be expected. With specific enzyme immunoassays, almost all patients with classic PAN are negative for p-ANCA.

Anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies (MPO-ANCA or p-ANCA) are also seen in patients eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). While EGPA can also manifest with fever, malaise, tender cutaneous nodules, chest pain, and hypertension with increased creatinine (due to RPGN), the absence of respiratory tract involvement (e.g., asthma, sinusitis), which is characteristic of EGPA, makes this diagnosis less likely. Furthermore, renal aneurysms would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of anti-proteinase 3 antibodies (PR3-ANCA or c-ANCA) in the serum suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which can cause systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, myalgia), chest pain, livedo reticularis, tender cutaneous nodules, and hypertension with increased creatinine due to RPGN. However, renal aneurysms would not be expected. With specific enzyme immunoassays, almost all patients with classic PAN are negative for c-ANCA.
questions.hint: This patient has systemic and cutaneous features of vasculitis such as fever, weight loss, myalgia, tender cutaneous nodules (due to panniculitis), livedo reticularis (lacy pink lesions), and increased ESR. The presence of aneurysms and renal vessel stenosis make polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of well-controlled hypertension is hospitalized after experiencing 5 weeks of chills, sweats, and fatigue, as well as a 6.8-kg loss in body weight. Two weeks before hospitalization, he developed acute left flank pain that resolved over a period of one week. He also notes progressively worsening postprandial abdominal pain and pain in his left testicle. His current blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg.
Laboratory testing identifies a C-reactive protein level of 124 mg/L (reference range, 0.08–3.10). Urinalysis reveals 2+ hematuria and 1+ proteinuria without red-cell casts. The serum creatinine level is normal. Antinuclear antibody, antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody, and antiphospholipid antibody tests are negative.
A noncontrast CT of the abdomen reveals evidence of an area of renal infarction on the left. A renal angiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis that causes injury to vessels too small to be seen on angiography (arterioles, capillaries, and venules). Although MPA can also involve small arteries, there are always findings attributable to destruction of smaller vessels. For example, in the kidney, MPA causes glomerulonephritis, usually with red-cell casts detectable in the urine sediment. Unlike PAN, MPA is strongly associated with antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) with specificity for antimyeloperoxidase (anti-MPO) antibodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV is an inherited condition of vascular fragility that typically manifests before age 40. It is associated with large-vessel dissection, not intrarenal aneurysms.

C) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), a necrotizing vasculitis of small to medium-sized arteries, causes microaneurysms and stenoses leading to ischemia, infarction, and bleeding. Common features of PAN include weight loss, myalgia, peripheral neuropathy, skin lesions, other symptoms and findings of tissue ischemia or infarction in a wide range of organs (including the testicles, uterus, or ovaries), and hypertension if branches of the renal arteries are involved. Active hepatitis B virus infection can be an associated factor. Angiography of visceral arteries often shows aneurysms and/or stenoses or occlusions, and biopsy of affected areas often reveals inflammatory cell infiltration into and fibrinoid necrosis of the walls of small arteries, in addition to tissue destruction.

Key learning point: Multiple renal and/or mesenteric microaneurysms on angiography are most likely to suggest a diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibromuscular dysplasia causes a noninflammatory thickening in the walls of large arteries, most often the renal arteries, leading to stenoses. Most cases are in women.

E) INCORRECT:

Polycystic kidney disease causes cysts in the kidneys and can be associated with brain aneurysms but not intrarenal aneurysms.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman with a history of intravenous heroin use is hospitalized with fever, pain in the small joints of the hands and feet and in her lower legs between the knees and ankles, and severe, constant, left-sided abdominal pain. The fever and joint pain, associated with morning stiffness, began one week ago. The abdominal pain, which started 2 days ago, is what prompted her to seek medical care.
On examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. She has a temperature of 38.8°C, a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 168/104 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while she is breathing ambient air. Multiple metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are swollen and tender bilaterally. Multiple tender subcutaneous nodules about 0.5 cm in diameter are detected in the lower legs. Costovertebral angle tenderness is present on the left.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7200
4500–11,000


Hematocrit (%)
33.6
36.0–46.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
452,000
150,000–350,000


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
98
1–25


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.8
0.6–1.1


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
326
0–35


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
248
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
120
30–120


Urinalysis findings are 2+ blood, 2+ protein, negative leukocyte esterase, and no red-cell casts.
Hepatitis B surface antigen testing is positive; hepatitis B surface antibody testing is negative; antinuclear antibody titer is 1:40. Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, and blood-culture results are all negative. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiograms show no valvular abnormalities.
CT of the abdomen without contrast reveals a wedge-shaped density in the cortex of the left kidney.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although antiphospholipid syndrome can lead to renal infarcts, it typically does not cause joint pain or fever unless associated with lupus.

B) INCORRECT:

Endocarditis, lupus, and vasculitides affecting small vessels (arterioles, capillaries, and venules), such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s), are each appropriate considerations with this clinical scenario, but the laboratory and imaging findings (negative blood cultures and echocardiograms, very low titer antinuclear antibody, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, and absence of red-cell casts) make each of them unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Endocarditis, lupus, and vasculitides affecting small vessels (arterioles, capillaries, and venules), such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s), are each appropriate considerations with this clinical scenario, but the laboratory and imaging findings (negative blood cultures and echocardiograms, very low titer antinuclear antibody, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, and absence of red-cell casts) make each of them unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a vasculitis affecting medium- to small-sized arteries. It can be primary or associated with another etiology, most often hepatitis B virus infection. Renal involvement is common, but because PAN spares the capillaries, it does not lead to glomerulonephritis; rather, it causes renal infarcts and renovascular hypertension due to involvement of the renal arteries. Gastrointestinal involvement, the most severe manifestation of PAN, can lead to bowel perforation.

Mesenteric angiography demonstrating microaneurysms is very suggestive of PAN in the appropriate clinical setting. When associated with hepatitis B virus infection, PAN typically occurs within the first 6 months of the infection. Treatment requires immunosuppression and antiviral therapy.

Key learning point: A vasculitis of medium- to small-sized arteries that is associated with hepatitis B virus infection is polyarteritis nodosa.

E) INCORRECT:

Endocarditis, lupus, and vasculitides affecting small vessels (arterioles, capillaries, and venules), such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s), are each appropriate considerations with this clinical scenario, but the laboratory and imaging findings (negative blood cultures and echocardiograms, very low titer antinuclear antibody, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, and absence of red-cell casts) make each of them unlikely.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of chest pain and palpitations over the past two months. During this time, he has experienced a 4-kg weight loss, malaise, bilateral knee pain, and diffuse myalgias. He was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection five years ago and has been taking tenofovir since then. His temperature is 38°C, pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal except for tachycardia. There are several ulcerations around both ankles and calves. Laboratory studies show the following:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
110 g/L (125–170)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
14.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), blood
80 mm/h (0–10)


Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
Negative


Hepatitis B surface antigen
Positive


Protein, urine
+2


RBC, urine
6–7/hpf


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by progressive inflammation and thrombosis that results in claudication with absent peripheral pulses and cold extremities. It may cause ulcerations of the distal extremities and muscle pain. However, findings would usually include migratory thrombophlebitis and Raynaud's phenomenon, as well as normal ESR levels. Thromboangiitis obliterans would also not explain the involvement of multiple organ systems.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener's granulomatosis) can manifest with malaise, arthralgias, skin lesions, as well as renal and cardiac symptoms and increased ESR. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia) suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Churg-Strauss syndrome is a type of small vessel vasculitis that may present with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms. However, patients with Churg-Strauss syndrome often have a history of recurrent asthma attacks and positive testing for pANCA.

D) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that often manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms. However, patients with microscopic polyangiitis commonly have pulmonary symptoms (e.g., hemoptysis). Furthermore, individuals with microscopic polyangiitis are pANCA positive in ∼ 70% of cases.

E) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), like most vasculitides, usually involves multiple organ systems, as seen in this patient (skin, kidneys, heart). The absence of pANCA and pulmonary symptoms, as well as the association with hepatitis B (and hepatitis C), helps to differentiate PAN from other forms of vasculitis. Muscle biopsy of this patient would most likely show transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

PAN should be always considered in young adults presenting with stroke or myocardial infarction.

Key learning point: Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium-vessel vasculitis associated with hepatitis B, presenting with multisystem involvement, skin ulcers, renal findings, and negative ANCA serology.
questions.hint: This patient presents with nonspecific symptoms (fever, arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain, palpitations), and renal manifestations (proteinuria, hematuria), as well as elevated ESR and leukocytosis, all of which are findings consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. A negative pANCA and a history of a hepatitis B infection indicate a certain subtype of vasculitis that usually spares the lungs.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of diffuse muscle pain, malaise, bilateral knee pain, and recurrent episodes of abdominal and chest pain. He reports a 5-kg weight loss over the past 4 months. He was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection 4 years ago and has been taking tenofovir since then. On examination, there are several ulcerations around both ankles and calves. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are negative. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria and hematuria. Muscle biopsy shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that often manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as well as fibrinoid necrosis, as seen here. However, patients with microscopic polyangiitis commonly have pulmonary symptoms, (e.g., hemoptysis). Furthermore, individuals with microscopic polyangiitis are p-ANCA positive in ∼ 70% of cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by progressive inflammation and thrombosis that results in claudication with absent peripheral pulses and cold extremities. It may cause ulcerations of the distal extremities and muscle pain, as seen in this patient. However, findings would usually include migratory thrombophlebitis and Raynaud's phenomenon. Thromboangiitis obliterans would also not explain the involvement of multiple organ systems, and the biopsy findings in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that can manifest with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as seen here. However, patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis often have a history of recurrent asthma attacks and positive testing for p-ANCA. Furthermore, biopsy typically reveals tissue eosinophilia with granulomatous reactions.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can manifest with malaise, arthralgias, skin lesions, as well as renal and cardiac symptoms, as seen in this patient. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia) suggests a different diagnosis. Furthermore, biopsy typically shows necrotic, partially granulomatous vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels.

E) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) like most vasculitides, usually involves multiple organ systems, as seen in this patient (skin, kidneys, heart). The absence of p-ANCA and pulmonary symptoms, as well as the association with Hepatitis B (and C), helps to differentiate PAN from other forms of vasculitis. Muscle biopsy typically shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis, as seen in this patient. Other typical characteristics of PAN include a high ESR level, proteinuria, and hematuria. PAN should be always considered in young adults presenting with stroke or myocardial infarction.

Key learning point: Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium-vessel vasculitis associated with hepatitis B, characterized by multisystem involvement, negative ANCA, and transmural arterial inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with several nonspecific symptoms (arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (several ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain), gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain), and renal symptoms (proteinuria, hematuria) is consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. His negative p-ANCA, hepatitis B infection, and biopsy findings indicate a certain subtype of vasculitis that usually spares the lungs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fever, unintentional 7 kg (∼15-pound) weight loss, and severe muscle and joint pain. He reports recent onset of left foot drop and numbness in his right hand. Physical examination reveals blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg, temperature of 38.4°C (101.2°F,) bilateral painful skin changes affecting the lower extremities (see photograph), and decreased sensation in the right hand and left leg. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis, elevated ESR and CRP, and mild proteinuria. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone and discharge with rheumatology follow-up
Admit for nerve conduction studies and urine delta aminolevulinic acid levels
Admit for tissue biopsy of purpura and urgent rheumatology consultation
Order chest CT to evaluate for lung involvement and determine disposition

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While glucocorticoids are part of treatment for this condition, starting treatment without confirming the diagnosis would be inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

While lead toxicity can cause polyneuropathy, the combination of systemic constitutional symptoms, hypertension, skin involvement, and elevated inflammatory markers strongly suggests a systemic vasculitis rather than toxic neuropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis may be considered for patients with life-threatening PAN refractory to pharmacotherapy or those with hepatitis B-associated PAN, but it is not first-line therapy. The diagnosis must first be confirmed, and standard immunosuppressive therapy should be initiated under rheumatology guidance.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's presentation of constitutional symptoms, peripheral neuropathy (mononeuritis multiplex), hypertension, skin involvement, negative ANCA, and history of hepatitis B infection strongly suggests polyarteritis nodosa. Tissue biopsy of accessible affected tissue (muscle or skin) is required to confirm the diagnosis, and urgent rheumatology consultation is essential for coordinating immunosuppressive therapy and ongoing management of this systemic vasculitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary evaluation would not be helpful in this clinical context as the patient has respiratory symptoms and the suspected diagnosis typically spares the lungs. The results of a CT chest would not affect disposition.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of fever, myalgia, and a 6.8-kg (15-lb) unintentional weight loss. Over the past 3 weeks, he has developed painful nodules on his shins and weakness in his right foot. He has a history of chronic hepatitis B infection. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), and blood pressure is 162/94 mm Hg. Examination shows tender, erythematous subcutaneous nodules on the lower extremities and an inability to dorsiflex the right foot. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 95 mm/hr. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mesenteric angiography can be a useful diagnostic tool for polyarteritis nodosa, as it may show characteristic microaneurysms in the visceral arteries. However, mesenteric angiography is reserved for patients with clinical evidence of abdominal arterial involvement (e.g., abdominal pain, GI bleeding, or ischemia) or when tissue biopsy cannot be obtained. Furthermore, it is a specialized and invasive procedure and is not the most appropriate initial management step.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's fever, elevated inflammatory markers, and painful skin nodules could raise suspicion for an infectious process. However, the 2-month duration of symptoms, significant weight loss, and specific neurologic finding of a foot drop are not typical for a bacterial infection. This approach would fail to address the underlying condition and would inappropriately delay the correct diagnosis and treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

While high-dose corticosteroids are a cornerstone of treatment for polyarteritis nodosa, initiating them empirically without a confirmed diagnosis is not recommended, as it can obscure the clinical picture, delay a definitive diagnosis, and expose the patient to significant side effects. Furthermore, in cases associated with hepatitis B, immunosuppression must be carefully coordinated with antiviral therapy, a decision best managed by a specialist.

D) CORRECT:

An urgent rheumatology consultation is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis of PAN, which is typically made via biopsy or angiography. The association with chronic hepatitis B and a negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody test is consistent with the diagnosis. High-dose corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide are standard treatments for severe PAN, but in cases associated with hepatitis B, antiviral therapy is essential and should be managed by a specialist.PAN is a complex, potentially life-threatening condition requiring specialized diagnosis and management.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of constitutional symptoms, mononeuritis multiplex (foot drop), tender skin nodules, and history of hepatitis B virus (HBV) is highly suggestive of HBV‑associated polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of fever, a 10-lb unintentional weight loss, and diffuse muscle aches. Over the past month, he has developed worsening pain in his left lower leg and difficulty lifting his foot. He also reports intermittent, crampy abdominal pain that is worse after meals. His medical history is significant for hypertension. On examination, his temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F) and blood pressure is 168/98 mm Hg. There is a faint, lace-like purplish rash on his lower extremities. Neurologic examination shows weakness with dorsiflexion of the left foot. Laboratory studies show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) serology is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), a systemic necrotizing vasculitis of medium-sized arteries. Key features include constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss), myalgias, and evidence of end-organ ischemia. The foot drop signifies mononeuritis multiplex from vasculitis of the vasa nervorum. Abdominal pain after meals suggests mesenteric ischemia or “intestinal angina.” The lace-like rash is livedo reticularis, and new-onset hypertension can result from renal artery involvement. PAN characteristically spares the lungs and is typically ANCA-negative. A significant portion of cases is associated with hepatitis B infection, for which this patient should be tested.

B) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger disease) involves small and medium-sized vessels of the extremities, which could explain this patient's leg pain. However, it is almost exclusively seen in heavy smokers and typically presents with distal limb ischemia, Raynaud phenomenon, and superficial thrombophlebitis. The systemic features seen in this patient, such as fever, weight loss, and abdominal pain, are not characteristic of this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a small-vessel vasculitis that can cause constitutional symptoms. However, its hallmark feature is pulmonary-renal syndrome, with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis being common manifestations. This patient has no pulmonary symptoms. Additionally, microscopic polyangiitis is strongly associated with a positive p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA).

D) INCORRECT:

This small-vessel vasculitis can cause constitutional symptoms, myalgias, and neuropathy. However, the classic cutaneous manifestation is palpable purpura, not livedo reticularis. While neuropathy can occur, the specific combination of mononeuritis multiplex and intestinal angina is less typical. This condition is also strongly associated with hepatitis C infection and the presence of cryoglobulins in the serum.

E) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a systemic vasculitis that can present with constitutional symptoms and neuropathy. However, it is a small and medium–sized vessel vasculitis that classically involves the upper respiratory tract (e.g., sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (e.g., hemoptysis), and kidneys (glomerulonephritis). This patient does not have any sinopulmonary findings. Furthermore, this condition is strongly associated with a positive c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA).
questions.hint: Focus on the size of the vessels implicated by this patient's symptoms, such as mononeuritis multiplex and intestinal angina, and correlate this with the negative ANCA serology.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of diffuse muscle pain, malaise, pain in both knees, recurrent episodes of abdominal and chest pain. He has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. Four years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection and was started on tenofovir. There are several ulcerations around the ankle and calves bilaterally. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are negative. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Muscle biopsy shows a transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis typically manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), as seen here. However, this patient lacks important findings of GCA (e.g., pulse-synchronous throbbing, dull headache, temporal tenderness, and jaw claudication). Although GCA is also often associated with polymyalgia rheumatica that typically manifests with proximal muscle pain (shoulder, pelvic girdle) and stiffness, this patient has diffuse muscle and knee pain. Lastly, GCA is most common in women over 50 years of age, and unlike the biopsy findings in this patient, temporal artery biopsy typically shows granulomatous panarteritis, mononuclear cell infiltrates, and giant cell formation within the vessel wall.

B) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), like most vasculitides, usually involves multiple organ systems, as seen in this patient (skin, kidneys, heart). The absence of p-ANCA and pulmonary symptoms, as well as the association with Hepatitis B (and C), helps to differentiate PAN from other forms of vasculitis. Muscle biopsy typically shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis, as seen in this patient. Other typical characteristics of PAN include a high ESR level, proteinuria, and hematuria. PAN should always be considered in young adults presenting with stroke or myocardial infarction.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can manifest with malaise, arthralgias, skin lesions, as well as renal and cardiac symptoms, as seen in this patient. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia) suggests a different diagnosis. Furthermore, biopsy typically shows necrotic, partially granulomatous vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels.

D) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by progressive inflammation and thrombosis that results in claudication with absent peripheral pulses and cold extremities. It may cause ulcerations of the distal extremities and muscle pain, as seen in this patient. However, findings would usually include migratory thrombophlebitis and Raynaud's phenomenon. Thromboangiitis obliterans would also not explain the involvement of multiple organ systems, and the biopsy findings in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that can manifest with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as seen here. However, patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis often have a history of recurrent asthma attacks and positive testing for p-ANCA. Furthermore, biopsy typically reveals tissue eosinophilia with granulomatous reactions.

F) INCORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis often manifests with fever, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia, muscular pain, and cardiac symptoms (angina pectoris), all of which are findings in this patient. It is also associated with chronic hepatitis B. However, Takayasu arteritis typically manifests with decreased bilateral brachial and radial pulses (“pulseless disease”). Moreover, it typically occurs in Asian females under the age of 40 years, and unlike the biopsy findings in this patient, Takayasu arteritis typically manifests with granulomatous thickening of the aortic arch.

G) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that often manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as well as fibrinoid necrosis, as seen here. However, patients with microscopic polyangiitis commonly have pulmonary symptoms, (e.g., hemoptysis). Furthermore, individuals with microscopic polyangiitis are p-ANCA positive in ∼ 70% of cases.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with several nonspecific symptoms (arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (several ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain), gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain), and renal symptoms (proteinuria, hematuria) is consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. His negative p-ANCA, hepatitis B infection, and biopsy findings indicate a certain subtype of vasculitis that usually spares the lungs.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of diffuse muscle pain, malaise, pain in both knees, recurrent episodes of abdominal and chest pain. He has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. Four years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection and was started on tenofovir. There are several ulcerations around the ankle and calves bilaterally. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are negative. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Muscle biopsy shows a transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) like most vasculitides, usually involves multiple organ systems, as seen in this patient (skin, kidneys, heart). The absence of p-ANCA and pulmonary symptoms, as well as the association with Hepatitis B (and C), helps to differentiate PAN from other forms of vasculitis. Muscle biopsy typically shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis, as seen in this patient. Other typical characteristics of PAN include a high ESR level, proteinuria, and hematuria. PAN should be always considered in young adults presenting with stroke or myocardial infarction.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can manifest with malaise, arthralgias, skin lesions, as well as renal and cardiac symptoms, as seen in this patient. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia) suggests a different diagnosis. Furthermore, biopsy typically shows necrotic, partially granulomatous vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels.

C) INCORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by progressive inflammation and thrombosis that results in claudication with absent peripheral pulses and cold extremities. It may cause ulcerations of the distal extremities and muscle pain, as seen in this patient. However, findings would usually include migratory thrombophlebitis and Raynaud's phenomenon. Thromboangiitis obliterans would also not explain the involvement of multiple organ systems, and the biopsy findings in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that can manifest with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as seen here. However, patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis often have a history of recurrent asthma attacks and positive testing for p-ANCA. Furthermore, biopsy typically reveals tissue eosinophilia with granulomatous reactions.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small vessel vasculitis that often manifests with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss), arthralgia, skin lesions, and renal symptoms, as well as fibrinoid necrosis, as seen here. However, patients with microscopic polyangiitis commonly have pulmonary symptoms, (e.g., hemoptysis). Furthermore, individuals with microscopic polyangiitis are p-ANCA positive in ∼ 70% of cases.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with several nonspecific symptoms (arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (several ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain), gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain), and renal symptoms (proteinuria, hematuria) is consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. His negative p-ANCA, hepatitis B infection, and biopsy findings indicate a certain subtype of vasculitis that usually spares the lungs.
